Award.AwardTitle: Industry Self-Regulation: Effectiveness, Third Party Certification and Regulatory Holiday

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Industry self-regulation has been adopted as a complement to traditional government-directed regulation even in high-risk industries, such as the chemical and nuclear sectors. This research asks: can self-regulation programs reduce risks and if so, how should these programs be designed? The researach team approaches this question by examining Responsible Care (RC), the self-regulation program in the chemical sector, and its impact on reducing occupational hazards. RC, which exemplifies key features of industry self-regulation programs, has been broadly adopted worldwide and emulated by other industries.

This project examines the impact of RC on workplace safety, a main focus of the program. Poor management of production processes caused the devastating Bhopal accident, an event that contributed to the creation of RC. Therefore, RC has stipulated codes of conduct on Process Safety and Employee Health and Safety, aimed at reducing risks in the production processes including occupational hazards. This empirical project builds upon the authors? constructed dataset of the US chemical manufacturing sector (2,735 plants owned by 1,523 firms), incorporating economic, environmental, and demographic variables. This research expands this database by linking it to OSHA?s Inspection and Accident databases, and extends the period studied to the years 2002-2007. The expanded data set allows the research team to study the introduction of third party certification into RC in 2002 in order to isolate its effects. If third party certification improves the effectiveness of self-regulatory programs in reducing risks, managers may seek to include credible certification into such programs. The research also examines the effect of participation in RC on regulatory scrutiny.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Voluntary and self-regulatory programs are being used as policy tools to reduce the health and environmental impacts of industries. The use of such programs has become prevalent, in part, due to declining regulatory budgets. The overriding question is to what extent these programs are effective at reducing the health and environmental impacts of industries. Relatedly, can these programs act as substitutes to regulatory programs, or should these programs be best treated as complements to traditional regulatory programs?

The first two papers from this project, both published in the Journal of Regulatory Economics, examines the Responsible Care (RC) program, a worldwide self-regulation program, whose codes of conduct include pollution reduction beyond existing regulations and accident reduction. The National Commission on the BP Oil Spill, pointing to the success of RC, has recommended that the offshore oil drilling industry adopt self-regulation. Given policymakers’ interest in relying on self-regulation as one strategy to reduce industrial accidents, our study provides the first evaluation of the impact of self-regulation on accidents. We find that participation in the RC program does reduce accidents significantly. In contrast, our earlier paper finds that participation in the RC program did not significantly reduce pollution, measured as pollution reported to the Toxic Release Inventory (TRI). These studies, taken together, indicate that the underlying regulatory framework plays an important role in determining whether the self-regulation program achieves its stated goals. Plants adhere to the RC program’s goal of improving safety because they face lower potential liability when their likelihood of accidents declines. In contrast, plants do not adhere to the program’s goal of reducing pollution because reducing the TRI pollutants, many of which are unregulated, would not yield profits Therefore, it is premature to rely on similarly designed self-regulation programs, i.e., without third-party certification or penalties for non-performance, to reduce pollution.  The RC program did begin to require third-party certification after the period covered by this study.

The third paper from this project, published in Ecological Economics, examines the impact of mandatory pollution disclosure programs on worker exposure to pollution. These programs aim to reduce pollution into the environment by requiring plants to publicly report their emissions into the environment. A prominent example of a disclosure program that has been emulated worldwide is the Toxic Release Inventory program (TRI). Because strategies to reduce emissions and occupational exposure are interlinked, the EPA has initiated discussions on the potential role of these mandatory programs in occupational health policy. Our study is the first to test if pollution disclosure programs can achieve the complementary goal of reducing workers’ exposure. Our study finds that workers’ exposure declined significantly by 11% at a time corresponding with the implementation of the TRI program. However, we find only limited evidence of larger reduction in workers’ exposure in plants that operated in industries that are more responsive to the TRI program. Our results on the limited effect of the TRI program in reducing worker exposure are compatible with results from surveys of plants managers. They report that TRI program contributes to reductions in both emissions and worker exposure only when plants receive additional technical assistance to modify their production technologies.
